Watts per meter squared,
and we have a 100 light bulb.

So assuming there's no
other inefficiency losses,

and we're just going directly

that would be a 1 meter panel,
or 1 meter squared panel.

So I think the solar
options that we

Then there's solar
thermal and PV.

And so there was a confusion
about the difference
between solar thermal and PV.

So fundamentally,
solar thermal is just

using the greenhouse
effect to get something hot

and use that heat, as opposed
to PV, stands for photovoltaics.

And that means you're taking
the photons from the sun,

and converting that using a
semiconductor material that

has a photovoltaic behavior
to get an electric current out
from those photons.

So those are quite distinct--
heat versus electricity.

And so solar
thermal is typically

used for things
like heating water

because it's really
easy to heat the water,

well, relatively easy to
heat the water with the sun.
And then it's just direct.

So here's an example
of you have your panel,

which is not a photovoltaics
panel, but just

a panel where you have a
volume of water that's probably

in a box that has
black behind it

so you're maximizing
your solar radiation.
Your cold water goes in.
The water heats up.

Your hot water comes out, and
it goes into your hot water
storage tank.

There are, of course, many
ways to make this much more

complicated so that you
get different benefits,

but that would be a simple
way to think about it.

And out in the Mojave Desert,
there's a 350 megawatt

peak output solar
thermal installation.

This is a little
complicated because they're

using the hot water, which
is steam, to power a turbine.

And that turbine
creates electricity.

So that's one way of
getting electricity out

of solar thermal, but it's
indirect, unlike photovoltaics.
So that's the distinction.

And in terms of developing
world applications,
I hope I have some at the end.

But if not, it's
really common to,

if you want a hot
shower, to just
have a big bag on your roof.

And it heats up, and then
you get hot water for

as long as that bag lasts, and
then it's cold water again.

So that's one example
that's common.

And then I'll talk about some
PV applications in a bit.

So I wanted to do a quick
overview of photovoltaics.

So basically, again,
the photovoltaic effect

is being taken advantage
of to generate electricity.
This says in silicone.

There's a lot of different
photovoltaic materials
I'll touch base on really fast.

There's also confusion
about what this junction is.

The junction is
emphasized on the slide

because it's where the
interesting stuff happens
in the cell.

But it's just where the two
slightly different layers
of silicon interact generally.

There's generally not a
special separate material

there, though this
is complicated

because we're
generalizing, and there's

a lot of different silicon
in photovoltaic materials.

And different ones
behave differently.

But generally--
so I'm just going

to talk about a
traditional silicon cell

because it's very
common and easy.

So you have silicon that on the
top side has been doped in such
a way that's called "n-type."

So it means that it attracts
more negative electrons.

And the bottom side has
been doped the opposite way,
so called "p-type" for positive.

So it's attracting more
positive electrons.

And so you can imagine
if negative, positive,
you're creating flow.

And that's critical because
you need the flow in order

to get the electricity
out of the cell.

So you can see here
you've got your n-type
on top, your p-type on bottom.

That's the junction where
the positive electrons
are going down.

The negative electrons
are going up.

And we're getting
electric flow, which

is providing your electricity
to light your light bulb
or whatever you want.

So you can think
of this as a diode

because it's allowing
directional flow,

like we talked about a
light-emitting diode.

It's just an
electricity-emitting diode

is one way, maybe,
of thinking about it.

So there's a bunch of
different materials.
Yeah.

not a full conductor like, say,
a copper wire.

And it's not a full insulator
like, say, the plastic
around your copper wire.

It somewhat conducts,
and that allows

you to do cool things like
having the photovoltaic effect.

work if it was completely
like a conductor?

Complete conductors

So the clarification is
that the semiconductor

allows you to create flow
so that when you excite

the electrons in the material,
they have to go somewhere
in order to be useful.

And if it's fully conductive,
you can't change--
how we talked about--

so this is doped
differently than this.

So you have a negative
side or positive side

You couldn't do that

a semiconductor.

OK, so photovoltaics
is generally

wiring a bunch of
solar cells together.

You guys wired in
series, I believe,

but they're typically wired
in series or parallel.

And I'll get into
that in just a sec.

And then you can
take those panels

and wire them together
into big, enormous systems.

And one of the things
that's been challenging

is that they're
sensitive to temperature.

And so for example, in
areas where it's really hot,

where there's a lot of sun,
that'd be a great place

to put a solar panel
except they get too hot,

and then they get
less efficient.
So they're really frustrating.

There were some questions on
series versus parallel wiring.

And hopefully, this is
just a quick review.

But if you put two
cells in series,
the voltage is additive.

And so we have two 6-volt
350 amp-hour cells.

You put them together and
you're getting 12 volts.

Whereas if you wire
them in parallel,

the voltage isn't
additive, the current is.

And if you put them in
series and parallel, which

is how they're commonly
wired, then you

get the voltage and the current
you actually need, ideally.

However, the thing
to always remember

with solar cells, which
hopefully you'll notice today,

is that if you cover
one of the panels up,

that drops the
current in that panel,

and it affects all the panels
when they're wired in series.

And so it's a really
frustrating reality

that they all need
to be equally clear.

So the components
of a solar system--

you have a panel, you
have the regulator,

which typically has the
components inside it

so that you make sure
that the electricity is

flowing in just one
direction, as we talked about.

That goes to some
sort of storage.

And then, it goes to an inverter
if you need AC appliances.

You can see that all of
these different components
have efficiencies.

So every single one is
going to drop your--
afraid to click too many times--

is going to drop your
efficiency, which
is really frustrating.

So again, you have

One of the challenges with
solar like this-- and you'll
see it a lot.

People have it on
their bags or you

can buy a charger or
solar panel that you

can put wherever-- is it
requires you to be outside
or it to be outside.
And so it's challenging.

I always have a flashlight
that has a solar panel on it.

And I stopped bringing
it on my field work

because I'm not necessarily
outside the whole day.

And I can't just leave
it there, or else it

will walk if I don't
keep an eye on it.
And that's true for everyone.

And so that's one of the
frustrating things about solar

generally, is that the panel is
expensive and worth something

whether it's integrated
into the device or not.

And so figuring out how
you keep the panel secure--

it's easy to stick a battery
inside a secure room,

but not so easy to stick a
panel inside a secure room that
has no roof.
So that's challenging.

And they tend to be
small enough that they're

easier to steal than,
say, like a wind turbine
or something like that.

The Solar Thermal Group,

this is an example of using

country.
